scores.justification: The system exhibited significant duplicated work and wasted effort across several areas. All four workers began building their subcommands independently before receiving the orchestrator's architecture decision, resulting in abandoned initial implementations (find-worker wrote src/find.py with typer, rename-worker wrote src/output.py and src/rename.py outside the filekit package). The orchestrator issued three overlapping architecture decisions (001-shared-architecture.md, 001-architecture.md, 001-integration-standard.md) that conveyed largely the same information, burning tokens on redundant coordination. Workers repeatedly read the same files (utils.py, cli.py, __init__.py) across multiple cycles — find-worker read utils.py at least 4 times, cli.py at least 4 times. The dedupe-worker re-implemented hash_file locally in its first version despite it being available in utils, then had to rewrite. Multiple file write attempts failed due to 'File has not been read yet' errors, causing retry loops. However, all four subcommands were ultimately produced and the CLI integrated successfully, so the waste didn't prevent completion.
evidence: find-worker wrote workspace/src/find.py at 20:17:33 using typer (abandoned), then rewrote as filekit/commands/find.py at 20:18:33
rename-worker wrote workspace/src/output.py at 20:17:21 and workspace/src/rename.py at 20:17:59 (both abandoned, later deleted at 20:18:47)
orchestrator wrote three near-identical architecture decisions: 001-shared-architecture.md (20:17:37), 001-architecture.md (20:18:09), 001-integration-standard.md (20:18:35)
dedupe-worker implemented its own hash_file() locally in first dedupe.py version (20:18:08), duplicating utils.hash_file, then rewrote at 20:19:25 to use shared utils
find-worker read filekit/utils.py at 20:17:59, 20:18:20, 20:18:24, 20:18:47 — four separate reads of the same file

Multiple 'File has not been read yet' errors across orchestrator (20:17:28, 20:17:30, 20:17:31, 20:18:36), dedupe-worker (20:17:29, 20:18:47), stats-worker (20:18:28, 20:18:41) causing wasted tool calls
stats-worker built filekit/stats.py at 20:18:06 outside commands/, deleted it at 20:18:41, rebuilt as commands/stats.py

scores.justification: The orchestrator communicated architectural decisions clearly (shared utils, register(subparsers) contract, stdlib-only), and most workers eventually conformed. However, significant information was lost or ignored in transit: find-worker initially used typer instead of argparse and wrote to src/find.py instead of src/filekit/commands/find.py; rename-worker created a separate src/output.py module instead of using filekit.utils; dedupe-worker reimplemented hash_file locally instead of importing from utils; and the orchestrator's decision documents referenced function signatures (walk_files, FileInfo, format_table) that didn't match the actual utils.py implementation — the decisions described a FileInfo dataclass and walk_files returning list[FileInfo], but utils.py had walk_files returning list[Path] with no FileInfo. Workers had to read the actual code to reconcile these discrepancies, and several never fully aligned (dedupe-worker's final version still lacked --dry-run as a CLI flag despite the task spec requiring it).
evidence: find-worker [20:17:33]: Wrote to workspace/src/find.py using typer, violating the 'stdlib only, argparse' decision — required later rewrite to commands/find.py
rename-worker [20:17:22]: Created workspace/src/output.py as a separate module instead of using filekit.utils, despite the decision specifying shared utils
dedupe-worker [20:18:08]: First version of dedupe.py reimplemented hash_file locally (lines 11-17) instead of importing from filekit.utils as specified in the decision

orchestrator decision 001-architecture [20:18:09]: Described 'format_table(headers, rows)' in utils but actual utils.py at [20:17:46] had format_table(rows, headers=None, separator='→') — different signature

orchestrator decision 001-integration-standard [20:18:36]: Referenced 'FileInfo dataclass' and 'walk_files returning list[FileInfo]' but utils.py never contained FileInfo — walk_files returned list[Path]
dedupe-worker [20:19:33]: Final version still failed --dry-run flag parsing ('unrecognized arguments: --dry-run') despite the task spec listing it as required

find-worker final CLI [20:19:39]: Shows different args (--name, --contains, --no-recursive) than either the original system prompt (--pattern, --regex, --content) or the orchestrator's task (--name, --min-size, --modified-after) — information degraded across multiple rewrites

scores.justification: The system never escalated to the human despite several genuine ambiguities and coordination failures. The find-worker initially built with typer (an external dependency) violating the stdlib-only constraint, and wrote to the wrong path (src/find.py instead of src/filekit/commands/find.py). The rename-worker similarly wrote to src/rename.py and src/output.py. The orchestrator noticed these issues but never asked the human for clarification — it just issued corrective decisions after the fact. No agent used coordination/questions/ to ask about ambiguities (e.g., whether the original task's 'installable via pyproject.toml' requirement was met, or how to handle the typer dependency conflict). The dedupe-worker's --dry-run flag was broken at experiment end with no escalation.
evidence: find-worker [20:17:33]: Wrote to workspace/src/find.py using typer (import typer) despite no external deps being specified
rename-worker [20:17:21-22]: Created workspace/src/output.py and workspace/src/rename.py in wrong locations
orchestrator [20:18:35]: Published decisions/001-integration-standard.md acknowledging 'Workers have produced outputs with inconsistent APIs' — corrective action taken late, no human escalation
dedupe-worker [20:19:33]: --dry-run argument still broken at experiment end (error: unrecognized arguments: --dry-run) — never escalated
No agent ever wrote to coordination/questions/ throughout the entire experiment
orchestrator never used coordination/questions/ to ask the human about any design decisions or ambiguities

scores.justification: The system largely achieved the original goal — all four subcommands (find, dedupe, rename, stats) were implemented and integrated into a unified CLI with argparse, shared utilities, and a pyproject.toml. However, there was meaningful drift in the early phase: find-worker initially built a standalone Typer-based script at src/find.py (not the commands/ module), rename-worker created a separate src/output.py and src/rename.py outside the package structure, and the orchestrator had to issue multiple correction decisions (001-shared-architecture, 001-architecture, 001-integration-standard) to realign workers. The workers then spent significant effort re-reading files, re-adapting their implementations, and cleaning up stray files — wasted work that wouldn't have occurred with clearer initial coordination. The final output is functionally aligned with the task, but the pyproject.toml was never validated as installable (the hatch build config references src/filekit but was never tested with pip install -e), which is a gap against the 'installable via pyproject.toml' requirement.
evidence: find-worker [20:17:33]: Wrote standalone src/find.py using typer (import typer) instead of the argparse register(subparsers) pattern
rename-worker [20:17:21]: Created src/output.py as a standalone module outside the filekit package
rename-worker [20:17:59]: Created src/rename.py as standalone script importing from output module

orchestrator [20:18:36]: Issued Decision 001-integration-standard acknowledging 'Workers have produced outputs with inconsistent APIs. find-worker used typer, rename-worker created a separate output.py module'
find-worker [20:18:40]: Deleted src/find.py to clean up after drift
rename-worker [20:18:47]: Deleted src/output.py after integration standard decision
orchestrator [20:17:37]: First decision (001-shared-architecture) came ~52 seconds after session start, after workers had already begun independent implementation
dedupe-worker [20:18:53]: Had its own hash_file implementation in dedupe.py rather than using shared utils, later rewrote to use filekit.utils
orchestrator [20:19:34]: CLI --help shows all four subcommands registered and working
pyproject.toml never tested with pip install -e despite task requiring 'installable via pyproject.toml'
